articles.headline: House Approves Border Aid, Seeking to Curb Trump’s Crackdown
articles.snippet: House Democrats pushed through $4.5 billion in humanitarian aid to address the plight of migrants at the southern border, after leaders quelled a revolt.
articles.abstract: House Democrats pushed through $4.5 billion in humanitarian aid to address the plight of migrants at the southern border, after leaders quelled a revolt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided House voted on Tuesday to send $4.5 billion in humanitarian aid to the border to address horrific conditions facing a crush of migrants, attaching significant rules on how the money could be spent in the first action by Democrats to rein in President Trump’s immigration crackdown.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: ‘Lock the S.O.B.s Up’: Joe Biden and the Era of Mass Incarceration
articles.snippet: He now plays down his role overhauling crime laws with segregationist senators in the ’80s and ’90s. That portrayal today is at odds with his actions and rhetoric back then.
articles.abstract: He now plays down his role overhauling crime laws with segregationist senators in the ’80s and ’90s. That portrayal today is at odds with his actions and rhetoric back then.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In September 1994, as President Bill Clinton signed the new Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act in an elaborately choreographed ceremony on the south lawn of the White House, Joseph R. Biden Jr. sat directly behind the president’s lectern, flashing his trademark grin.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: U.S. Tech Companies Sidestep a Trump Ban, to Keep Selling to Huawei
articles.snippet: Chip makers’ deals underscore how difficult it is to clamp down on companies that the administration considers a national security threat.
articles.abstract: Chip makers’ deals underscore how difficult it is to clamp down on companies that the administration considers a national security threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — United States chip makers are still selling millions of dollars of products to Huawei despite a Trump administration ban on the sale of American technology to the Chinese telecommunications giant, according to four people with knowledge of the sales.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Regulators Have Doubts About Facebook Cryptocurrency. So Do Its Partners.
articles.snippet: The social media company said it had signed 27 partners to its Libra project. But executives at some of those companies said they were approaching it warily.
articles.abstract: The social media company said it had signed 27 partners to its Libra project. But executives at some of those companies said they were approaching it warily.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of the biggest selling points of Facebook’s ambitious plans for its new cryptocurrency, Libra, was that the social media company had 27 partners, including prominent outfits like Visa, Mastercard and Uber, helping out on the project.

articles.headline: Mueller to Testify to Congress, Setting Up a Political Spectacle
articles.snippet: Robert S. Mueller III, the former special counsel, agreed to testify on July 17, two House panels said after issuing subpoenas to compel his appearance.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Mueller III, the former special counsel, agreed to testify on July 17, two House panels said after issuing subpoenas to compel his appearance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III, the former special counsel, has agreed to testify in public before Congress next month about his investigation into Russia’s election interference and possible obstruction of justice by President Trump, House Democrats announced on Tuesday night.

articles.headline: Buy Low-Tops, Sell High-Tops: StockX Sneaker Exchange Is Worth $1 Billion
articles.snippet: StockX is one of several online marketplaces that have turned resales of shoes into a big — and highly valued — business.
articles.abstract: StockX is one of several online marketplaces that have turned resales of shoes into a big — and highly valued — business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nic Wilkins started selling parts of his sneaker collection online two years ago as a way to make some extra cash in college. The hobby took off, and this year he expects to move 10,000 pairs of shoes. His anticipated take is a 25 percent profit from over $1 million in sales.

articles.headline: Boris Johnson, Political Escape Artist, Lands in Hot Water. Again.
articles.snippet: The front-runner to become the British prime minister is frequently caught in gaffes, oversights and outright lies. And that’s what his fans like about him.
articles.abstract: The front-runner to become the British prime minister is frequently caught in gaffes, oversights and outright lies. And that’s what his fans like about him.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is not an easy task to hold Boris Johnson to account. Ask John Palmer, who tried to do it 30 years ago, when they were both reporters covering Europe for British newspapers.
